awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Energy Aware Millimeter Wireless Data Communications in Multicore Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to develop efficient millimeter-wave chip-to-chip data communications for multicore processors. The approach is to develop small CMOS compatible antennas for data transfers. The project involves design, analysis, and measurement of millimeter wave antennas on silicon and the interface electronics for on-chip communications. This includes electromagnetic modeling, circuit simulation and measurement on prototypes. Special antennas will be created to ensure minimal interaction between the antennas used for data transfers and the nearby CMOS circuitry used for processing. 

The project's intellectual merits lie in its innovative approach to high-speed data transfers between integrated circuits in multicore computers. In processors with upwards of 100 cores, physical connections are complex and severely restrict performance. The use of the air-interface above the processors is a new concept for efficient data communications.  High efficiency on-chip multi-antenna arrays will enable programmable direct processor-to-processor communications. The antenna links will increase data rates, conserve power, and consume an extremely small area. 

The broader impacts of this research include potentially completely new computer architectures that enable fast computation of the world's largest problems, such as predictive models for severe weather forecasting. The research results will be used for a project for freshman college engineering courses and for elementary school demonstrations. Small low-profile antennas integrated onto Lego Mindstorms robots will be created so that the robots can communicate to one another wirelessly. Creation of this hands-on project is expected to improve recruitment and retention of a diversity of students in engineering.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits

Multicore computers that use more than 100 processing cores on a single chip promise unprecendented enhancement of computational performance. One challenge in creating these computers are the interconnections between computing cores (or chips.) Maximum computation performance can only be achieved with efficient data transfers between cores. The full promise of multicore systems cannot be realized unless efficient (both in energy and time) communications between cores is realized. Current technology using electrical interconnects is based on relatively few processors. Scientists and engineers have identified that novel research on the design, fabrication, and architecture of future multicore systems must address all hardware and software opportunities for computing system design. This project created compact antennas that can be placed on computing chips that allow wireless communication links between cores. The antennas were designed to work at 60GHz. Antennas at 60GHz are small enough to fit on computing cores, have wide instantaneous bandwidth for high speed data transfers, and can be integrated with existing 60GHz CMOS transceivers.

Over the grant period, the PI and her graduate research team designed and developed several 60GHz antennas for multi-RF data transmission. The antennas use a new layered ground plane technology that has been used by researchers in the field of RF "metamaterials." The layered ground plane allows small printed antennas to be placed on very thin dielectric materials and backed by a solid ground plane. A thin patterned layer is placed between the antenna and the solid (conventional) ground plane. The layered ground plane approach solves several technical challenges. First, the layered planes sets up the appropriate electromagnetic environment (or boundary condition) so that the antenna can effectively radiate in the direction of other computing chips and does so with efficiently (i.e., with high bandwidth and low reflection.) Second, the layered ground plane blocks any antenna radition into the CMOS chip. This prevents RF noise interactions between the circuits and the antenna. It also eliminates any signal loss into the silicon.

The team created several antennas and developed a design approach that could be utilized by other researchers. The designs were validated by fabricating antenna prototypes and comparing computed and measured results. The team also created several parameters that provide new ways to estimate the power savings in the wireless link. This will allow engineers who design computer networks to estimate the design tradeoffs between conventional interconnects and the new wireless interconnects.

The project produced a M.S. thesis, two Ph.D. dissertations, numerous journal and conference papers, two seminars at IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers) local chapter meetings, and three undergraduate student papers presented at the International Telemetry Conference. The PI has been invited to give a talk on this work for "On Chip Antennas" for EuCap (an international antennas conference) in Spring 2015.

 

Broader Impacts

Three graduate students have been involved. Sixteen undergraduate students have been involved in antenna  and telemetry research related to this project. Half of the undergraduate students are underrepresented minorities or women. The telemetry projects are co-advised with Prof. Michael Marcellin with funding from the International Telemetering Foundation.
